utterances: But by 2008, that good will had eroded completely.
Now speaking on Fox News shortly after his win, Steele addressed that very issue.
(Soundbite of Fox News Sunday interview)
Just because a black man is running the RNC doesn't mean black folks are going to go, oh, OK now, I'll be a Republican.
Just as with the election of President Obama, all the problems and concerns that are very important to African-Americans don't get solved overnight.
There are still black businesses that are being red-lined and neighborhoods that are struggling.
So what I think it do is send the appropriate message that right now, at this hour, the Republican Party gets it.
Well, Renee, he's certainly right.
Just because he's black doesn't mean blacks are going to flock to him.
But the question that I have for you is will the Republican Party expect him to deliver blacks because he's been elected to that position?
Absolutely.
They really are.
They really are.
So what's going to have to happen, you got to go out and talk to folks.
Just because he's African-American and we're trying to pull minorities, not just African-Americans into the party, doesn't mean they are going to flock over.
We have to go out with the right message and pull people back in the party.
People really flipped because they didn't like our message, like you all just alluded to, and so we have to get back on track.
In order to do that, first he has to get the message together.
He has to get some resources.

He has to get some field people out there to know what they're doing so that then they'll come not just because Michael Steele is black, it has made a good statement, a different statement but because they believe in the values that the Republican Party believe in.
What values would those be, George, that would be appealing to blacks in larger numbers than they've had so far?
You know, we're talking about the whole faith-based piece.
I mean, George Bush started the whole faith-based initiative.
Obama had said that he would, you know, continue that.
You know, African-Americans in particular believe into those things.
Economic development, that's a very big deal for us.

You know, to make sure that small businesses survive, you know, that we have a seat at the table, and those are just few of the things that, you know, that he has to start dealing with in getting this message together and out there.
I think that's what spoke to you, wasn't it, George, as a small black businessman?
Yeah, I mean, you know, I just felt that the traditional black - if you want to call them black leaders or the Democratic Party didn't speak to me.

And I think the issue with a lot of African-Americans with the Republican Party is they've made a lot of mistakes in terms of communicating, not knowing how to communicate to African-Americans, and making honest mistakes in terms of policy.
And so, I think one of the things that is not mentioned, too, is sometimes in the past the party just happened to have a black face and not a person as credible in the black community.
So I think that's also important to Michael Steele where black folks cannot label him, you know, to be honest, Uncle Tom or something.
And I think that's a real benefit of having someone like him who, quote, is considered - even if you don't agree with him - quote, he's a good brother.
I think that's an important part of what bring him along also.
How will the evangelicals in the party take to him, Renee?
You know, it depends on how Michael goes out and talks to them.
He has to go out and pull people in.
He basically did that in order to win this election also.
I have to be honest, Michael Steele worked that floor.
I was sitting there watching him talking to people, saying - the bottom line is he has to listen.
He started listening to people, and that's what sold people on him.
He listened.
All that whole weekend he worked, and not even after the last two years, Michael has been going out trying to pull people in in that particular sector also, and he'll continue to do that.
He has to do it.
The question that I have as we bring this to a close, George, is for you, and it's this.

It would just seem to me that the job that Michael Steele has to try to put a new face on the Republican Party at a time that America is just really enthralled with Barack Obama as president, both Republicans and Democrats who are supporting him, that's a really uphill battle.
Well, Tony, I'm a student of history, and you know, if you look at history, things change over a period of time, and I'm sure President Obama will do a good job.
I think - it's just like when Tom Bradley(ph) became mayor here and people were very excited.
After a period of time you have to govern, you have to deal with day-to-day issues.
And so I think as time that goes by and people settle in to the adjustment of a black president that the core issues will be such that people will be more open to looking at the full spectrum.
Well, we'll certainly have an opportunity to find out, won't we?
Absolutely.
Mid-term elections are only two years away.
That's the first acid test for the new black chairman of the Republican Party.
Thank you both very much for coming on.
Thank you for having me.
That was Renee Amoore.
She is deputy chair of the Republican Party of Pennsylvania.
We also heard from George Davis.
He is a management consultant based in Los Angeles and president of Davis Broadband Group and International Media and Entertainment Consultancy Group.
He joined me right here at the studios of NPR West.
(Soundbite of music)
Just ahead, will a new coalition agreement in Zimbabwe finally bring political peace to the Southern African nation?
And what happens when you blend the sounds of East Africa, jazz and Latin rhythms?
We'll talk to the Duke Ellington of Ethiopia, Mulatu Astatke.
Our Africa update is next.
(Soundbite of music)
This is NPR News.
I'm Farai Chideya and this is News & Notes.
Staycation.
It's one of those newfangled words that's caught on fast.
A vacation is when you vacate.
You take off, you stay in a hotel, or camp out, or see the sights.
A staycation is - well, you got it.
With soaring gas prices and plane tickets, this was supposed to be the summer of staying at home.
But was that prediction off the mark?
If you're thinking about traveling soon or for the winter holidays, what should you keep in mind?
With us to talk about both of those issues we've got Madeline Nunn, senior travel agent with the Richmond, Virginia, branch of the American Automobile Association, or Triple-A.
Hi, Madeline.
How are you?
I'm great.
So, back in May, a Rand McNally survey found that two-thirds of Americans planning road trips this summer said they would shorten their trips or cancel them all together.
Summer is wrapping up, so what actually panned out?
Well, actually, the staycation thing is sort of a myth, so to speak, because Americans are traveling.
They're traveling because they are hard-working and they need the rest and the revitalization.
They need this vacation.
So, what we're finding is that they're not staying home, per se.
Some are just staying a little closer to home.
And sometimes they're limiting the length of time that they may take for this vacation.
Well, give me an example, since you deal with people who are trying to plan their trips.
Give me an example of someone you talked to who changed their behavior at least a little bit.
All right.
One thing they do, they may decide to - they may decide to, instead of using a car or air travel, they may decide to use Amtrak.
We've seen a very large increase in train travel.
They may decide to travel off-peak times versus peak times, because the price will be slightly less.
They may decide to stay in a two- or a three-diamond resort rather than staying in a four- or five-diamond resort, which can bring the price down also.
So, those are some of the things they're doing.
You know, limiting the time.
Maybe if they had planned seven nights, they may just take five nights.
But they're going to take that vacation nevertheless.
Traveling can be expensive for families that have kids, because obviously it can be a whole bunch of people that you need to take care of, not just one or two.
So, did anything change for families in particular?
Well, some families have decided to drive.
And what we have found out is that driving approximately is only going to cost them maybe 20 dollars more, per say, to drive on a vacation.
This year, (unintelligible) last year, unless you're driving across country, that is.
So, it's only about 20 dollars more, basically.
And some people have decided instead of putting all the family on a plane, they may drive to a vacation.
They may take a spot that may be a little closer to home also.
And that will decrease the cost of the trip.
Of course, where you go can make a big difference in what you spend.
If you go to New York City on vacation, you're going to spend one amount of money.
If you go camping, you might spend a very different amount of money.
Do you see people making choices on that level as well?
The pipeline has been built to pump more than a million barrels of oil a day from offshore platforms all the way to waiting tanker ships in the Mediterranean Sea.
With oil reaching record prices of more than $70 a barrel this week, that's a lot of money for Azerbaijan.
And Patrick Tracey, thank you very much for being with us today.
There is an opportunity for people who are interested in either purchasing a home or refinancing a mortgage that they already have.
They can find great rates at the large lenders.
Of course credit history is going to be very important, and we've seen banks certainly tighten up the flow of loans that they're making and raise the standards for borrowers who get those loans.
But that said, for the interested home buyer or home refinancer there are good rates out there.
It's just a question of where you go to look.
So how do you decide whether this is the time for you to refinance?
I think it's a question of actually going out and doing the leg work.
If you can get a significantly lower rate, which a lot of borrowers who I interviewed for this story say that they got, it's a great time to refinance.
Now, borrowers shouldn't stop at the big lenders and assume that the rates that the top three lenders are offering them is all that's out there, 'cause that's certainly not true.
There's a plethora of other lenders, actually, that sometimes can provide much better rates.
Like...
Community banks, regional banks, credit unions, and independent mortgage brokers, actually.
On average, what we saw in our research was that rates were lower at the regional lenders and independent mortgage brokers than they were at the top three lenders.
And the top three lenders are Chase, Wells Fargo, and Bank of America.
There was a tremendous amount of refinancing going on right before the so-called housing bubble broke.
If you have refinanced your mortgage already, does it make sense to refinance it again?
It does.

If you're not happy with the conditions that you've refinanced into, which a lot of people aren't - they thought that what they were getting was a good deal back before the housing bubble burst, they were less concerned about adjustable rate mortgages, which I think people now are very concerned about, they want to lock in a fixed rate for the duration of their mortgage - you can absolutely go back to a variety of lenders and refinance your mortgage again.
Just because you've done it once doesn't mean that that's it.

There are a lot of people who perhaps need refinancing the most, those people whose mortgages are underwater, where their houses are worth less than the amount of money they've borrowed to pay for them.
Can folks who are underwater do this?
They can.
They can.
Again, it depends on credit history, really, and it depends on the credit profile of the person.
Now, what we're seeing is that the best rates are really only available to people with very pristine credit profiles.
That means high credit scores, no delinquencies, no delinquencies in mortgage payments.
And so while we're talking about good rates being available, some would say it's unfortunate that they're only available to a subset of the population that fits this credit profile.
Thank you very much.
Thank you.
Jessica Silver-Greenberg is a reporter with the Wall Street Journal.
All this week on MORNING EDITION we're exploring the politics of oil.
And this morning, we begin traveling a pipeline that cuts across several national borders, and is of interest to some of the world's great powers.
The pipeline opens this summer at a cost of more than $4 billion.
It's expected to send oil 1,000 miles from the Caspian seacoast in the former Soviet Union to the Mediterranean Sea.
NPR's Ivan Watson traveled the length of that pipeline.
And in the first of a three-part series, Ivan reports on the pipeline's beginning in Azerbaijan, which hopes to quadruple its oil exports.
Azerbaijan already has more than a century of experience with oil and the money that comes with it.
